This paper delves into the legal complexities surrounding the protection of non-Earth satellites, specifically lunar satellites within the expanding cislunar space, and focuses on the emerging cyberthreats confronting these satellites within the burgeoning lunar economy, drawing parallels with Earth's satellite security to anticipate future challenges. Highlighting the intricate nature of cyber threats and their impact on both governmental and commercial satellites, this paper examines cyberattacks as potential international wrongful acts and armed attacks. This paper evaluates the right of affected states to self-defense and scrutinizes Article IV of the Outer Space Treaty ("OST"), alongside other pertinent treaties' provisions. This paper concludes that Article IV of the OST should not be interpreted as to impede the right of self-defense for lunar satellites, and claims that the inherent right of self-defense overrides the OST's restrictions, allowing for protection for lunar satellite assets.

# I. INTRODUCTION

This paper discusses the legal issues of protecting satellites in lunar (and other non-earth) orbits from cyberattacks. Lunar satellites are included in the "cislunar" space¹ but present special characteristics that differentiate them from the satellites around Earth. This paper focuses on lunar satellites due to the expanding cislunar and lunar economy. This expansion is expected to result in an escalation of cyberrisks for lunar satellites—particularly for commercial ones, which have less robust protection compared to their military counterparts.² Similar to Earth-orbiting satellites³—upon which our economy has come to rely—which are facing growing threats from competitors and adversaries openly expressing their intention to disrupt these satellites in times of conflict,⁴ lunar satellites are likely to face the same threats, with the expansion of the lunar economy.⁵

Due to the limited number of satellites currently orbiting the Moon, this paper analyses the threats faced by Earth's satellites and derives insights applicable to lunar satellites. Potential adversaries are constantly trying to capitalize on perceived weaknesses in space capabilities,⁶ and satellites are exposed to several threats (including physical/kinetic, non-kinetic/physical, electronic, and cyber); however, this paper focuses on

This paper will discuss in Part III(E) and Part IV, respectively, cyberattacks as international wrongful acts and cyberattacks as “armed attacks.”¹¹ In both cases, the affected state has a right to react, albeit with differing degrees of severity. Article 2.4 of the Charter of the United Nations (“UN Charter”)¹² prohibits use of force or threat thereof.¹³ Self-defense (including collective self-defense as in the North Atlantic Treaty)¹⁴ stands as an exception as per Article 51 of the UN Charter, incorporating a fundamental principle within customary international law.¹⁵ This paper examines if a cyberattack qualifies as use of force, granting affected states the right to countermeasures, and, if the cyberattack escalates to an armed attack, whether self-defense permits the use of force or threat thereof.¹⁶

Lunar activities will rely on satellites in various ways. First, for lunar communication: in order to maintain contact with assets on the lunar surface, lunar satellites will serve as communication relay stations, enabling data transfer, audio/video communication, and command and control of lunar rovers/other equipment.58 Upcoming lunar missions anticipate reliance on emerging cislunar space networks, comprising a special network for communication including relay satellites, orbiters, and spacecraft.59 With the establishment of a stable presence on the Moon, the communication need will be even more pressing. ## B. WHY SATELLITES ARE PARTICULARLY EASY TARGETS FOR CYBERATTACKS

A satellite could be attacked kinetically or non-kinetically. “Kinetic” means actions involving physical force or direct contact, such as bombings and other types of attacks that cause physical damage, while “non-kinetic” attacks are those that do not involve a direct physical force. A cyberattack—the focus of this paper—is a form of non-kinetic attack being carried out by digital means to compromise, disrupt, or damage data, infrastructure, or communication. The term “cyberattack” has several definitions, including the following: “deliberate actions to alter, disrupt, deceive, degrade, or destroy computer systems or networks or the information and/or programs resident or transiting these systems or networks.” Cyberattacks are performed through malware, hacking, denial-of-service, and other tactics aimed at compromising or disrupting computer systems, networks, and data. A cyberattack can aim at stealing sensitive information, or causing system malfunctions, or blocking the system (unblocking it only after the payment of a sum of money called ransomware).

## C. THE IMPORTANCE OF SATELLITE CYBERSECURITY

Satellites play a critical role in many sectors, including national security, banking, weather monitoring, communication, and navigation.[100] Therefore, satellites are prized targets for cyberattacks. As countries increase their investment in satellites, they also grow more reliant on them, thereby creating a higher potential reward for hostile entities capable of disrupting their operations.[101] In some cases, compromising a satellite can be an expeditious way of attacking adversaries in an international conflict, and—as discussed in Part IV—a cyberattack of a satellite could be the most ius in bello-compliant way to perform an attack on a satellite.

Considering all the above, both government and commercially operated satellites must implement robust cybersecurity measures to ensure their protection. These measures include encryption of data, secure communication protocols, intrusion detection systems, and continuous monitoring to detect and respond to cyberthreats promptly.

E. SATELLITE CYBERATTACKS AS INTERNATIONALLY WRONGFUL ACTS

1. General Discussion Regarding Cyberattacks as Internationally Wrongful Acts

Even if uncertainties exist, numerous states, including the U.S., hold the view that the current international legal framework adequately governs the conduct of states in cyberspace.¹⁴¹ According to international law, a cyberattack could fall along the spectrum of international responsibility, use of force, and possibly armed attack. The boundaries between these scenarios are not always clearly defined.

International responsibility comes into play when there is a violation of an obligation attributable to a state. An international wrongful act—which is a foundational principle in customary international law—causes a novel legal relationship to arise between states when there is a breach of an international obligation by one of them. In fact, the breach triggers a shift from a primary rule—which is a rule dictating state conduct—to a secondary set of rules of responsibility. Article 2 of the Articles on State Responsibility for Internationally Wrongful Acts (“ARSIWA”)¹⁴² defines an international wrongful act as a conduct—either action or omission—that is contrary to what a State is required to do by international law, including violations of treaties and customary international law, that is attributable to the State. When the breach is attributable to a state, it initiates a new relationship called a “secondary rule,” which evokes legal consequences for the breaching state. Articles 28–36 of ARSIWA outline the legal ramifications of an internationally wrongful act. The legal framework aims to resolve disputes peaceably without escalating to war. It encompasses the obligation of the breaching state to cease the wrongful conduct, prevent its recurrence, rectify the situation, pay damages, or give satisfaction.

Rule 14 of the Tallinn Manual (“Internationally wrongful cyber acts”)¹⁴³ provides that a state bears international responsibility for a cyber-related act that is attributable to a state and that constitutes a breach of an international legal obligation. The focus is on acts that are less severe than the use of force, but still carry international repercussions, such as the obligation to provide reparation.

An internationally wrongful act denotes a transgression that falls short of constituting an armed assault, but imposes accountability upon the state.¹⁴⁴ Accountability exists only if an internationally wrongful act can be legally attributed to a state.¹⁴⁵ This can be shown by establishing that the state performed the cyberattack directly, the cyberattack was performed by non-state actors whose actions are attributable to the state,¹⁴⁶ or that a state offered help to another.¹⁴⁷ Legal attribution in case of non-state actors is difficult for cyberattacks on Earth, while in space it should be easier since Article VI stipulates that states bear “international responsibility for national activities in outer space,” regardless of whether these activities are conducted by governmental or non-governmental bodies. Article VI outlines principles that simplify attribution—a challenging aspect in terrestrial contexts. This is confirmed by Rule 60 of the Tallinn Manual, providing (a) that states have a duty of a state to “authorise and supervise the cyber ‘activities in outer space’ of its non-governmental entities,” and (b) that “[c]yber operations involving space objects are subject to the responsibility and liability regime of space law.” However, due to the broadly stated principles and obligations outlined in the OST and the lack specific state practices regarding claims for violating OST duties, the circumstances allowing for an internationally wrongful act concerning breaches of duties on the Moon remain uncertain.¹⁴⁸

## IV. IUS AD BELLUM AND IUS IN BELLO AND THEIR APPLICATION TO SATELLITE CYBERATTACKS

According to the proverbial expression "all is fair in love and war," in matters of love and times of war, almost any action is considered acceptable. This paper does not intend to delve into the accuracy of the statement concerning matters of love, but certainly the expression is quite wrong for wars, which are far from being unregulated in international law. In fact, armed conflicts are governed by two distinct bodies of law. The first governs the initiation of an armed conflict (ius ad bellum).^[189]^ The second governs the conduct of hostilities (ius in bello). This second body of law is also known as laws of armed conflict ("LOAC") or as international humanitarian law ("IHL").

Article 2.4 of the UN Charter¹⁹² provides that “[a]ll Members must abstain from the threat or use of force in their international relations against a state’s territorial integrity or political independence of any State, or in any manner inconsistent with the Purposes of the United Nations.” This provision establishes the principle of non-aggression, rendering the use of force, threats of force, including acts of aggression and military interventions, illegal against a state’s territorial integrity or political independence. Notably, it also prohibits any use or threat of force that contradicts the United Nations’ purposes. Three instances exist where the prohibition of use of force within or against another state is lawful: (1) that state’s consent; (2) authorization from the UN Security Council; and (3) individual or collective self-defense.¹⁹³

This paper does not discuss the topic of states’ consent¹⁹⁴ or the UN Security Council’s authorization;¹⁹⁵ and it focuses on the right of self-defense, as specifically relevant to a reaction to a cyberattack on a satellite. Self-defense is a principle of customary international law, which is also recognized by Article 51 of the UN Charter, which qualifies it as “the inherent right of individual or collective self-defense.”¹⁹⁶ This right exists whether exercised individually or collectively by states (as under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization treaty).¹⁹⁷ Under the principle of self-defense, a state is allowed to employ force when confronted with an “armed attack.” Nevertheless, the pivotal issue lies in the definition of an “armed attack,” which ultimately determines the applicability of the right to self-defense.¹⁹⁸

The UN Charter does not provide a specific definition for the term “armed attack,” and records from the UN Charter’s drafters provide no definitive explanation of the term.¹⁹⁹ Scholars suggest that the inexplicit definition of “armed attack” may exist because the concept was thought to be self-evident. Rule 72 (“Necessity and proportionality”) of the Tallinn Manual provides “[a] use of force involving cyber operations undertaken by a State in the exercise of its right of self-defense must be necessary and proportionate.”²⁴⁴

As the scope of a legitimate self-defense in cyberspace is debatable, afflicted countries are generally cautious when responding to cyberattacks due to the potential for escalation. Typically, diplomatic avenues are prioritized over immediate military or cyber counterattacks in retaliation. Lastly, as for physical attacks, collective self-defense (e.g., NATO) is also allowed.²⁴⁵

## 2. Ius in Bello and Its Application to Satellite Cyberattacks

The *ius in bello* governs the conduct of the hostilities, and has evolved over centuries. The *jus in bello* includes the laws of armed conflict (“LOAC”), alternatively known as international humanitarian law (“IHL”).²⁴⁶ This paper takes the position that IHL applies to conflicts in outer space,²⁴⁷ considering that the ICJ held that the IHL “applies to all forms of warfare and to all kinds of weapons, those of the past, those of the present, and those of the future.”²⁴⁸ Consistent is the Tallinn Manual, which unambiguously provides that “[c]yber operations executed in the context of an armed conflict are subject to the law of armed conflict.”²⁴⁹ However, contrary opinions exist.²⁵⁰ There is limited discourse on applying IHL to satellites in lunar or other celestial bodies’ orbits, which is not surprising considering the early stage of the lunar economy and the presence of only a few satellites around the Moon. However, once the principle of IHL applying in outer space is accepted, there is no reason to restrict IHL application to Earth’s orbits.

This paper only briefly outlines IHL principles and examines their application in space, specifically focusing on satellites. The following discussion will briefly cover: (1) military necessity; (2) distinction; (3) proportionality; (4) precautions; (5) the principle of constant care; and (6) the principle of avoiding widespread, long term, and severe damage to the natural environment. ## B. THE OTHER SPACE TREATIES AND INTERNATIONAL SPACE ARRANGEMENTS

### 1. The Other Space Treaties

After the OST was enacted in 1967, several other significant treaties were signed between 1968 and 1976. These treaties, namely the Rescue Agreement,³¹⁶ Liability Convention,³¹⁷ and Registration Convention,³¹⁸ also pertain to Moon activities and Moon satellites. None of these treaties are highly pertinent to the subject of this paper, except for the Liability Convention, which could be relevant if a cyber-attack results in measurable damage for which the victim-state seeks compensation.

In 1979—the Moon Agreement was signed³¹⁹—and it could have had the potential to significantly influence the subject of this paper. However, this treaty ultimately failed due to the limited number of ratifications. Therefore, while differing opinions exist,³²⁰ this paper contends that the dismissal of the Moon Agreement by the vast majority of states³²¹ (including all major space-faring nations except India and Australia) renders it largely irrelevant for our analysis. However, as previously discussed, it can still serve a purpose when employed in a contrasting manner to enhance our understanding of the interpretation of OST. In other words, if the Moon Agreement found it necessary to address a particular issue, it implies that the OST does not cover that aspect.

## B. NATO’s POSITION

The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (“NATO”), established in 1949 through the North Atlantic Treaty,³⁶⁵ is a political and military alliance created as a collective defense organization among North American and European countries, totaling thirty-two members.³⁶⁶ Collective defense is NATO’s bedrock: NATO members pledge to consider an attack against any of its members as an attack against all, triggering a duty to respond collectively.³⁶⁷ Equally significant is the aspect of defense planning, meaning that the members collaborate on planning their defense and developing military capabilities against security challenges. Also crucial is the aspect of cooperative security, which means that NATO cooperates with non-member countries and international organizations to promote security and stability, such as conventional military threats, terrorism, and hybrid warfare, and cyberattacks.

To comprehend NATO’s stance on cyberattacks targeting satellites, it is essential to recognize that the matter resides at the intersection of NATO’s position on satellite defense and its response to cyberattacks. NATO has been increasingly focused on protecting and defending its members’ satellites, considering that satellites are crucial to communication, navigation, reconnaissance, and military operations. In 2019, NATO officially recognized space as an operational domain “alongside air, land, sea and cyberspace.”³⁶⁸

2. Russia

Notwithstanding numerous declarations to the effect that space must be reserved for peaceful purposes,³⁸⁸ evidence exists that Russia continues in the militarization of space. Russian space law—largely governed by Federal Law No. 5663³⁸⁹—stipulates that space activities must adhere to legal provisions for safeguarding state secrets, military and commercial secrets, intellectual property, and exclusive rights. This suggests that the federal law acknowledges Russia's intention to utilize space for military purposes.³⁹⁰ Despite some progress in national security space capabilities, the Russian space industry is currently grappling with an era of stagnation.³⁹¹

Lately, Russia has heightened its efforts in developing antisatellite systems, with some of these efforts being publicly disclosed. Additionally, Russia has been engaged in the creation of orbital maneuvering satellites, potentially for tasks related to inspection and interception. The advancement in these technologies not only hints at Russia's intention to target reconnaissance and communication satellites, but also signifies a growing unease within Russia regarding the perceived weaponization of space by others.³⁹² Given Russia's long history of imperialism, reasonable doubts exist that its advocacy for peace in space might stem more from its current limited space capabilities, rather than from a genuine desire for space to remain a sanctuary. ## VII. CONCLUSION

This paper has delved into the issue of cyber-threats for satellites in non-Earth orbits, particularly in lunar orbits, amid escalating cyber-risks. The growing cislunar and lunar economy will heighten vulnerability, especially for commercial lunar satellites lacking robust protection. Just as Earth-orbiting satellites have faced increasing threats, lunar satellites will be confronted with similar risks in the expanding lunar economy. With a limited number of satellites orbiting the Moon, this paper has drawn insights from threats facing Earth's satellites to anticipate risks for lunar counterparts, focusing specifically on cyberthreats. Cyberthreats pose unique challenges due to attribution complexities and scope of the right of self-defense. This paper has examined cyberattacks as international wrongful acts and as armed attacks, assessing affected states' rights to self-defense. Considering provisions in the UN Charter and the OST, this paper has concluded that Article IV of the OST cannot be interpreted as impeding the right of self-defense of lunar satellites. Even if certain restrictions exist, this paper has argued that the right of self-defense would prevail when constrained by these limitations. Preserving security for both government and commercial satellites remains crucial for U.S. national interests, and it will become paramount on the Moon as well. The recognition that the right of self-defense is not diminished in space is an important component of satellite security.

Lunar satellites are included in the "cislunar" space¹ but present special characteristics that differentiate them from the satellites around Earth. ## B. WHY SATELLITES ARE PARTICULARLY EASY TARGETS FOR CYBERATTACKS
A satellite could be attacked kinetically or non-kinetically. “Kinetic” means actions involving physical force or direct contact, such as bombings and other types of attacks that cause physical damage, while “non-kinetic” attacks are those that do not involve a direct physical force. A cyberattack—the focus of this paper—is a form of non-kinetic attack being carried out by digital means to compromise, disrupt, or damage data, infrastructure, or communication. The term “cyberattack” has several definitions, including the following: “deliberate actions to alter, disrupt, deceive, degrade, or destroy computer systems or networks or the information and/or programs resident or transiting these systems or networks.” Cyberattacks are performed through malware, hacking, denial-of-service, and other tactics aimed at compromising or disrupting computer systems, networks, and data. A cyberattack can aim at stealing sensitive information, or causing system malfunctions, or blocking the system (unblocking it only after the payment of a sum of money called ransomware).

Satellites are prone to both kinetic and non-kinetic attacks because of their inherent characteristics. Scholars Georgeson and Stubbs explain that satellites are vulnerable due to several factors: (1) they are typically unshielded; (2) they follow predictable orbits, (3) they have limited maneuverability, (4) they are "few enough in number" that their destruction could have substantial repercussions; (5) replacing them is costly and consuming; and (6) numerous satellites have dual-use functionality, providing services to the military and to civilians, making them potential targets for enemy attacks.80
Not all of the factors mentioned above are equally relevant to protection against cyberattacks. As for shielding:81 while shielding against destructive attacks like kinetic anti-satellite missiles is difficult, protection against non-kinetic attacks is feasible (e.g., to safeguard against electronic attacks, a shutter shield could protect specific sensors or satellite lids; shielding could be effective against blinding lasers or dazzlers). Regarding the remote nature of operations, space systems are particularly vulnerable to cybersecurity threats due to the remote nature of their operations. Ground stations are also susceptible to cyberattacks;[95] if hackers access the ground station, they can seize control or disrupt the satellite. ## C. THE IMPORTANCE OF SATELLITE CYBERSECURITY
Satellites play a critical role in many sectors, including national security, banking, weather monitoring, communication, and navigation.[100] Therefore, satellites are prized targets for cyberattacks. As countries increase their investment in satellites, they also grow more reliant on them, thereby creating a higher potential reward for hostile entities capable of disrupting their operations.[101] In some cases, compromising a satellite can be an expeditious way of attacking adversaries in an international conflict, and—as discussed in Part IV—a cyberattack of a satellite could be the most ius in bello-compliant way to perform an attack on a satellite.
Considering all the above, both government and commercially operated satellites must implement robust cybersecurity measures to ensure their protection. These measures include encryption of data, secure communication protocols, intrusion detection systems, and continuous monitoring to detect and respond to cyberthreats promptly.

E. SATELLITE CYBERATTACKS AS INTERNATIONALLY WRONGFUL ACTS
1. General Discussion Regarding Cyberattacks as Internationally Wrongful Acts
Even if uncertainties exist, numerous states, including the U.S., hold the view that the current international legal framework adequately governs the conduct of states in cyberspace.¹⁴¹ According to international law, a cyberattack could fall along the spectrum of international responsibility, use of force, and possibly armed attack. The boundaries between these scenarios are not always clearly defined.
International responsibility comes into play when there is a violation of an obligation attributable to a state. An international wrongful act—which is a foundational principle in customary international law—causes a novel legal relationship to arise between states when there is a breach of an international obligation by one of them. In fact, the breach triggers a shift from a primary rule—which is a rule dictating state conduct—to a secondary set of rules of responsibility. Article 2 of the Articles on State Responsibility for Internationally Wrongful Acts (“ARSIWA”)¹⁴² defines an international wrongful act as a conduct—either action or omission—that is contrary to what a State is required to do by international law, including violations of treaties and customary international law, that is attributable to the State. When the breach is attributable to a state, it initiates a new relationship called a “secondary rule,” which evokes legal consequences for the breaching state. Articles 28–36 of ARSIWA outline the legal ramifications of an internationally wrongful act. The legal framework aims to resolve disputes peaceably without escalating to war. It encompasses the obligation of the breaching state to cease the wrongful conduct, prevent its recurrence, rectify the situation, pay damages, or give satisfaction.
Rule 14 of the Tallinn Manual (“Internationally wrongful cyber acts”)¹⁴³ provides that a state bears international responsibility for a cyber-related act that is attributable to a state and that constitutes a breach of an international legal obligation. The focus is on acts that are less severe than the use of force, but still carry international repercussions, such as the obligation to provide reparation.

An internationally wrongful act denotes a transgression that falls short of constituting an armed assault, but imposes accountability upon the state.¹⁴⁴ Accountability exists only if an internationally wrongful act can be legally attributed to a state.¹⁴⁵ This can be shown by establishing that the state performed the cyberattack directly, the cyberattack was performed by non-state actors whose actions are attributable to the state,¹⁴⁶ or that a state offered help to another.¹⁴⁷ Legal attribution in case of non-state actors is difficult for cyberattacks on Earth, while in space it should be easier since Article VI stipulates that states bear “international responsibility for national activities in outer space,” regardless of whether these activities are conducted by governmental or non-governmental bodies. Article VI outlines principles that simplify attribution—a challenging aspect in terrestrial contexts. This is confirmed by Rule 60 of the Tallinn Manual, providing (a) that states have a duty of a state to “authorise and supervise the cyber ‘activities in outer space’ of its non-governmental entities,” and (b) that “[c]yber operations involving space objects are subject to the responsibility and liability regime of space law.” However, due to the broadly stated principles and obligations outlined in the OST and the lack specific state practices regarding claims for violating OST duties, the circumstances allowing for an internationally wrongful act concerning breaches of duties on the Moon remain uncertain.¹⁴⁸

## IV. IUS AD BELLUM AND IUS IN BELLO AND THEIR APPLICATION TO SATELLITE CYBERATTACKS
According to the proverbial expression "all is fair in love and war," in matters of love and times of war, almost any action is considered acceptable. This paper does not intend to delve into the accuracy of the statement concerning matters of love, but certainly the expression is quite wrong for wars, which are far from being unregulated in international law. In fact, armed conflicts are governed by two distinct bodies of law. The first governs the initiation of an armed conflict (ius ad bellum).^[189]^ The second governs the conduct of hostilities (ius in bello). This second body of law is also known as laws of armed conflict ("LOAC") or as international humanitarian law ("IHL").

Article 2.4 of the UN Charter¹⁹² provides that “[a]ll Members must abstain from the threat or use of force in their international relations against a state’s territorial integrity or political independence of any State, or in any manner inconsistent with the Purposes of the United Nations.” This provision establishes the principle of non-aggression, rendering the use of force, threats of force, including acts of aggression and military interventions, illegal against a state’s territorial integrity or political independence. Notably, it also prohibits any use or threat of force that contradicts the United Nations’ purposes. Three instances exist where the prohibition of use of force within or against another state is lawful: (1) that state’s consent; (2) authorization from the UN Security Council; and (3) individual or collective self-defense.¹⁹³
This paper does not discuss the topic of states’ consent¹⁹⁴ or the UN Security Council’s authorization;¹⁹⁵ and it focuses on the right of self-defense, as specifically relevant to a reaction to a cyberattack on a satellite. Self-defense is a principle of customary international law, which is also recognized by Article 51 of the UN Charter, which qualifies it as “the inherent right of individual or collective self-defense.”¹⁹⁶ This right exists whether exercised individually or collectively by states (as under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization treaty).¹⁹⁷ Under the principle of self-defense, a state is allowed to employ force when confronted with an “armed attack.” Nevertheless, the pivotal issue lies in the definition of an “armed attack,” which ultimately determines the applicability of the right to self-defense.¹⁹⁸
The UN Charter does not provide a specific definition for the term “armed attack,” and records from the UN Charter’s drafters provide no definitive explanation of the term.¹⁹⁹ Scholars suggest that the inexplicit definition of “armed attack” may exist because the concept was thought to be self-evident. ## 2. Ius in Bello and Its Application to Satellite Cyberattacks
The *ius in bello* governs the conduct of the hostilities, and has evolved over centuries. The *jus in bello* includes the laws of armed conflict (“LOAC”), alternatively known as international humanitarian law (“IHL”).²⁴⁶ This paper takes the position that IHL applies to conflicts in outer space,²⁴⁷ considering that the ICJ held that the IHL “applies to all forms of warfare and to all kinds of weapons, those of the past, those of the present, and those of the future.”²⁴⁸ Consistent is the Tallinn Manual, which unambiguously provides that “[c]yber operations executed in the context of an armed conflict are subject to the law of armed conflict.”²⁴⁹ However, contrary opinions exist.²⁵⁰ There is limited discourse on applying IHL to satellites in lunar or other celestial bodies’ orbits, which is not surprising considering the early stage of the lunar economy and the presence of only a few satellites around the Moon. However, once the principle of IHL applying in outer space is accepted, there is no reason to restrict IHL application to Earth’s orbits.
This paper only briefly outlines IHL principles and examines their application in space, specifically focusing on satellites. The following discussion will briefly cover: (1) military necessity; (2) distinction; (3) proportionality; (4) precautions; (5) the principle of constant care; and (6) the principle of avoiding widespread, long term, and severe damage to the natural environment. ## 3. Article IV(2) of the OST
Article IV(2) of the OST provides that "the moon and other celestial bodies shall be used by all States Parties to the Treaty exclusively for peaceful purposes" and bans "[t]he establishment of military bases, installations and fortifications, the testing of any type of weapons and the conduct of military manoeuvres on celestial bodies." ### 1. The Other Space Treaties
After the OST was enacted in 1967, several other significant treaties were signed between 1968 and 1976. These treaties, namely the Rescue Agreement,³¹⁶ Liability Convention,³¹⁷ and Registration Convention,³¹⁸ also pertain to Moon activities and Moon satellites. None of these treaties are highly pertinent to the subject of this paper, except for the Liability Convention, which could be relevant if a cyber-attack results in measurable damage for which the victim-state seeks compensation.
In 1979—the Moon Agreement was signed³¹⁹—and it could have had the potential to significantly influence the subject of this paper. Therefore, while differing opinions exist,³²⁰ this paper contends that the dismissal of the Moon Agreement by the vast majority of states³²¹ (including all major space-faring nations except India and Australia) renders it largely irrelevant for our analysis. However, as previously discussed, it can still serve a purpose when employed in a contrasting manner to enhance our understanding of the interpretation of OST. ## B. NATO’s POSITION
The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (“NATO”), established in 1949 through the North Atlantic Treaty,³⁶⁵ is a political and military alliance created as a collective defense organization among North American and European countries, totaling thirty-two members.³⁶⁶ Collective defense is NATO’s bedrock: NATO members pledge to consider an attack against any of its members as an attack against all, triggering a duty to respond collectively.³⁶⁷ Equally significant is the aspect of defense planning, meaning that the members collaborate on planning their defense and developing military capabilities against security challenges. Also crucial is the aspect of cooperative security, which means that NATO cooperates with non-member countries and international organizations to promote security and stability, such as conventional military threats, terrorism, and hybrid warfare, and cyberattacks.
To comprehend NATO’s stance on cyberattacks targeting satellites, it is essential to recognize that the matter resides at the intersection of NATO’s position on satellite defense and its response to cyberattacks. NATO has been increasingly focused on protecting and defending its members’ satellites, considering that satellites are crucial to communication, navigation, reconnaissance, and military operations. In 2019, NATO officially recognized space as an operational domain “alongside air, land, sea and cyberspace.”³⁶⁸

## VII. CONCLUSION
This paper has delved into the issue of cyber-threats for satellites in non-Earth orbits, particularly in lunar orbits, amid escalating cyber-risks. The growing cislunar and lunar economy will heighten vulnerability, especially for commercial lunar satellites lacking robust protection. Just as Earth-orbiting satellites have faced increasing threats, lunar satellites will be confronted with similar risks in the expanding lunar economy. With a limited number of satellites orbiting the Moon, this paper has drawn insights from threats facing Earth's satellites to anticipate risks for lunar counterparts, focusing specifically on cyberthreats. Cyberthreats pose unique challenges due to attribution complexities and scope of the right of self-defense. This paper has examined cyberattacks as international wrongful acts and as armed attacks, assessing affected states' rights to self-defense. Considering provisions in the UN Charter and the OST, this paper has concluded that Article IV of the OST cannot be interpreted as impeding the right of self-defense of lunar satellites. Even if certain restrictions exist, this paper has argued that the right of self-defense would prevail when constrained by these limitations. Preserving security for both government and commercial satellites remains crucial for U.S. national interests, and it will become paramount on the Moon as well. The recognition that the right of self-defense is not diminished in space is an important component of satellite security.

This paper delves into the legal complexities surrounding the protection of non-Earth satellites, specifically lunar satellites within the expanding cislunar space, and focuses on the emerging cyberthreats confronting these satellites within the burgeoning lunar economy, drawing parallels with Earth's satellite security to anticipate future challenges. Highlighting the intricate nature of cyber threats and their impact on both governmental and commercial satellites, this paper examines cyberattacks as potential international wrongful acts and armed attacks. This paper evaluates the right of affected states to self-defense and scrutinizes Article IV of the Outer Space Treaty ("OST"), alongside other pertinent treaties' provisions. This paper concludes that Article IV of the OST should not be interpreted as to impede the right of self-defense for lunar satellites, and claims that the inherent right of self-defense overrides the OST's restrictions, allowing for protection for lunar satellite assets.

## B. WHY SATELLITES ARE PARTICULARLY EASY TARGETS FOR CYBERATTACKS
A satellite could be attacked kinetically or non-kinetically. “Kinetic” means actions involving physical force or direct contact, such as bombings and other types of attacks that cause physical damage, while “non-kinetic” attacks are those that do not involve a direct physical force. A cyberattack—the focus of this paper—is a form of non-kinetic attack being carried out by digital means to compromise, disrupt, or damage data, infrastructure, or communication. The term “cyberattack” has several definitions, including the following: “deliberate actions to alter, disrupt, deceive, degrade, or destroy computer systems or networks or the information and/or programs resident or transiting these systems or networks.” Cyberattacks are performed through malware, hacking, denial-of-service, and other tactics aimed at compromising or disrupting computer systems, networks, and data. A cyberattack can aim at stealing sensitive information, or causing system malfunctions, or blocking the system (unblocking it only after the payment of a sum of money called ransomware).

## C. THE IMPORTANCE OF SATELLITE CYBERSECURITY
Satellites play a critical role in many sectors, including national security, banking, weather monitoring, communication, and navigation.[100] Therefore, satellites are prized targets for cyberattacks. As countries increase their investment in satellites, they also grow more reliant on them, thereby creating a higher potential reward for hostile entities capable of disrupting their operations.[101] In some cases, compromising a satellite can be an expeditious way of attacking adversaries in an international conflict, and—as discussed in Part IV—a cyberattack of a satellite could be the most ius in bello-compliant way to perform an attack on a satellite.
Considering all the above, both government and commercially operated satellites must implement robust cybersecurity measures to ensure their protection. These measures include encryption of data, secure communication protocols, intrusion detection systems, and continuous monitoring to detect and respond to cyberthreats promptly.

E. SATELLITE CYBERATTACKS AS INTERNATIONALLY WRONGFUL ACTS
1. General Discussion Regarding Cyberattacks as Internationally Wrongful Acts
Even if uncertainties exist, numerous states, including the U.S., hold the view that the current international legal framework adequately governs the conduct of states in cyberspace. According to international law, a cyberattack could fall along the spectrum of international responsibility, use of force, and possibly armed attack. The boundaries between these scenarios are not always clearly defined.
International responsibility comes into play when there is a violation of an obligation attributable to a state. An international wrongful act—which is a foundational principle in customary international law—causes a novel legal relationship to arise between states when there is a breach of an international obligation by one of them. In fact, the breach triggers a shift from a primary rule—which is a rule dictating state conduct—to a secondary set of rules of responsibility. Article 2 of the Articles on State Responsibility for Internationally Wrongful Acts (“ARSIWA”) defines an international wrongful act as a conduct—either action or omission—that is contrary to what a State is required to do by international law, including violations of treaties and customary international law, that is attributable to the State. When the breach is attributable to a state, it initiates a new relationship called a “secondary rule,” which evokes legal consequences for the breaching state. Articles 28–36 of ARSIWA outline the legal ramifications of an internationally wrongful act. The legal framework aims to resolve disputes peaceably without escalating to war. It encompasses the obligation of the breaching state to cease the wrongful conduct, prevent its recurrence, rectify the situation, pay damages, or give satisfaction.
Rule 14 of the Tallinn Manual (“Internationally wrongful cyber acts”) provides that a state bears international responsibility for a cyber-related act that is attributable to a state and that constitutes a breach of an international legal obligation. The focus is on acts that are less severe than the use of force, but still carry international repercussions, such as the obligation to provide reparation.

## IV. IUS AD BELLUM AND IUS IN BELLO AND THEIR APPLICATION TO SATELLITE CYBERATTACKS
According to the proverbial expression "all is fair in love and war," in matters of love and times of war, almost any action is considered acceptable. This paper does not intend to delve into the accuracy of the statement concerning matters of love, but certainly the expression is quite wrong for wars, which are far from being unregulated in international law. In fact, armed conflicts are governed by two distinct bodies of law. The first governs the initiation of an armed conflict (ius ad bellum).^[189]^ The second governs the conduct of hostilities (ius in bello). This second body of law is also known as laws of armed conflict ("LOAC") or as international humanitarian law ("IHL").

Article 2.4 of the UN Charter provides that “[a]ll Members must abstain from the threat or use of force in their international relations against a state’s territorial integrity or political independence of any State, or in any manner inconsistent with the Purposes of the United Nations.” This provision establishes the principle of non-aggression, rendering the use of force, threats of force, including acts of aggression and military interventions, illegal against a state’s territorial integrity or political independence. Notably, it also prohibits any use or threat of force that contradicts the United Nations’ purposes. Three instances exist where the prohibition of use of force within or against another state is lawful: (1) that state’s consent; (2) authorization from the UN Security Council; and (3) individual or collective self-defense.
This paper does not discuss the topic of states’ consent or the UN Security Council’s authorization; and it focuses on the right of self-defense, as specifically relevant to a reaction to a cyberattack on a satellite. Self-defense is a principle of customary international law, which is also recognized by Article 51 of the UN Charter, which qualifies it as “the inherent right of individual or collective self-defense.” This right exists whether exercised individually or collectively by states (as under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization treaty). Under the principle of self-defense, a state is allowed to employ force when confronted with an “armed attack.” Nevertheless, the pivotal issue lies in the definition of an “armed attack,” which ultimately determines the applicability of the right to self-defense.
The UN Charter does not provide a specific definition for the term “armed attack,” and records from the UN Charter’s drafters provide no definitive explanation of the term. Scholars suggest that the inexplicit definition of “armed attack” may exist because the concept was thought to be self-evident. ## B. APPLICATION OF THE NOTION OF “ARMED ATTACK” TO CYBERATTACKS
In modern conflicts, cyberattacks can disrupt critical information assets, communications, and weapons systems. Cyberattacks can also cause political disruption by targeting finance, energy, transportation, and government services, thus creating social unrest. In sum, a cyberattack can inflict damage well beyond that of a single bombardment. Can a cyberattack be classified as "an armed attack" under the UN Charter? Our discussion centers on cyberattacks existing independently of larger warfare contexts, such as the Ukrainian war. The focus is on singular or multiple cyberattacks that, devoid of any other military actions, could be perceived as acts of aggression against national security.

## 2. Ius in Bello and Its Application to Satellite Cyberattacks
The *ius in bello* governs the conduct of the hostilities, and has evolved over centuries. The *jus in bello* includes the laws of armed conflict (“LOAC”), alternatively known as international humanitarian law (“IHL”). This paper takes the position that IHL applies to conflicts in outer space, considering that the ICJ held that the IHL “applies to all forms of warfare and to all kinds of weapons, those of the past, those of the present, and those of the future.” Consistent is the Tallinn Manual, which unambiguously provides that “[c]yber operations executed in the context of an armed conflict are subject to the law of armed conflict.” However, contrary opinions exist. There is limited discourse on applying IHL to satellites in lunar or other celestial bodies’ orbits, which is not surprising considering the early stage of the lunar economy and the presence of only a few satellites around the Moon. However, once the principle of IHL applying in outer space is accepted, there is no reason to restrict IHL application to Earth’s orbits.
This paper only briefly outlines IHL principles and examines their application in space, specifically focusing on satellites. The following discussion will briefly cover: (1) military necessity; (2) distinction; (3) proportionality; (4) precautions; (5) the principle of constant care; and (6) the principle of avoiding widespread, long term, and severe damage to the natural environment. Military necessity mandates that any action in an international armed conflict must be justified as necessary to gain a clear military advantage. Distinction requires a clear differentiation between civilians and combatants, as well as civilian and military objectives with operations directed solely at military objects. Military objectives are those contributing to military action through their nature, location, purpose, or use, and when their (partial or total) destruction, capture, or neutralization provides a clear military advantage. ## B. THE OTHER SPACE TREATIES AND INTERNATIONAL SPACE ARRANGEMENTS
### 1. The Other Space Treaties
After the OST was enacted in 1967, several other significant treaties were signed between 1968 and 1976. These treaties, namely the Rescue Agreement, Liability Convention, and Registration Convention, also pertain to Moon activities and Moon satellites. None of these treaties are highly pertinent to the subject of this paper, except for the Liability Convention, which could be relevant if a cyber-attack results in measurable damage for which the victim-state seeks compensation.
In 1979—the Moon Agreement was signed—and it could have had the potential to significantly influence the subject of this paper. However, this treaty ultimately failed due to the limited number of ratifications. Therefore, while differing opinions exist, this paper contends that the dismissal of the Moon Agreement by the vast majority of states (including all major space-faring nations except India and Australia) renders it largely irrelevant for our analysis. However, as previously discussed, it can still serve a purpose when employed in a contrasting manner to enhance our understanding of the interpretation of OST. In other words, if the Moon Agreement found it necessary to address a particular issue, it implies that the OST does not cover that aspect.

## B. NATO’s POSITION
The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (“NATO”), established in 1949 through the North Atlantic Treaty, is a political and military alliance created as a collective defense organization among North American and European countries, totaling thirty-two members. Collective defense is NATO’s bedrock: NATO members pledge to consider an attack against any of its members as an attack against all, triggering a duty to respond collectively. Equally significant is the aspect of defense planning, meaning that the members collaborate on planning their defense and developing military capabilities against security challenges. Also crucial is the aspect of cooperative security, which means that NATO cooperates with non-member countries and international organizations to promote security and stability, such as conventional military threats, terrorism, and hybrid warfare, and cyberattacks.
To comprehend NATO’s stance on cyberattacks targeting satellites, it is essential to recognize that the matter resides at the intersection of NATO’s position on satellite defense and its response to cyberattacks. NATO has been increasingly focused on protecting and defending its members’ satellites, considering that satellites are crucial to communication, navigation, reconnaissance, and military operations. In 2019, NATO officially recognized space as an operational domain “alongside air, land, sea and cyberspace.”

Despite some progress in national security space capabilities, the Russian space industry is currently grappling with an era of stagnation.
Lately, Russia has heightened its efforts in developing antisatellite systems, with some of these efforts being publicly disclosed. Additionally, Russia has been engaged in the creation of orbital maneuvering satellites, potentially for tasks related to inspection and interception. The advancement in these technologies not only hints at Russia's intention to target reconnaissance and communication satellites, but also signifies a growing unease within Russia regarding the perceived weaponization of space by others. ## VII. CONCLUSION
This paper has delved into the issue of cyber-threats for satellites in non-Earth orbits, particularly in lunar orbits, amid escalating cyber-risks. The growing cislunar and lunar economy will heighten vulnerability, especially for commercial lunar satellites lacking robust protection. Just as Earth-orbiting satellites have faced increasing threats, lunar satellites will be confronted with similar risks in the expanding lunar economy. With a limited number of satellites orbiting the Moon, this paper has drawn insights from threats facing Earth's satellites to anticipate risks for lunar counterparts, focusing specifically on cyberthreats. Cyberthreats pose unique challenges due to attribution complexities and scope of the right of self-defense. This paper has examined cyberattacks as international wrongful acts and as armed attacks, assessing affected states' rights to self-defense. Considering provisions in the UN Charter and the OST, this paper has concluded that Article IV of the OST cannot be interpreted as impeding the right of self-defense of lunar satellites. Even if certain restrictions exist, this paper has argued that the right of self-defense would prevail when constrained by these limitations. Preserving security for both government and commercial satellites remains crucial for U.S. national interests, and it will become paramount on the Moon as well. The recognition that the right of self-defense is not diminished in space is an important component of satellite security.

## B. WHY SATELLITES ARE PARTICULARLY EASY TARGETS FOR CYBERATTACKS
A satellite could be attacked kinetically or non-kinetically. “Kinetic” means actions involving physical force or direct contact, such as bombings and other types of attacks that cause physical damage, while “non-kinetic” attacks are those that do not involve a direct physical force. A cyberattack—the focus of this paper—is a form of non-kinetic attack being carried out by digital means to compromise, disrupt, or damage data, infrastructure, or communication. The term “cyberattack” has several definitions, including the following: “deliberate actions to alter, disrupt, deceive, degrade, or destroy computer systems or networks or the information and/or programs resident or transiting these systems or networks.” Cyberattacks are performed through malware, hacking, denial-of-service, and other tactics aimed at compromising or disrupting computer systems, networks, and data. A cyberattack can aim at stealing sensitive information, or causing system malfunctions, or blocking the system (unblocking it only after the payment of a sum of money called ransomware).

Satellites are prone to both kinetic and non-kinetic attacks because of their inherent characteristics. Scholars Georgeson and Stubbs explain that satellites are vulnerable due to several factors: (1) they are typically unshielded; (2) they follow predictable orbits, (3) they have limited maneuverability, (4) they are "few enough in number" that their destruction could have substantial repercussions; (5) replacing them is costly and consuming; and (6) numerous satellites have dual-use functionality, providing services to the military and to civilians, making them potential targets for enemy attacks.80
Not all of the factors mentioned above are equally relevant to protection against cyberattacks. As for shielding:81 while shielding against destructive attacks like kinetic anti-satellite missiles is difficult, protection against non-kinetic attacks is feasible (e.g., to safeguard against electronic attacks, a shutter shield could protect specific sensors or satellite lids; shielding could be effective against blinding lasers or dazzlers). ## C. THE IMPORTANCE OF SATELLITE CYBERSECURITY
Satellites play a critical role in many sectors, including national security, banking, weather monitoring, communication, and navigation.[100] Therefore, satellites are prized targets for cyberattacks. As countries increase their investment in satellites, they also grow more reliant on them, thereby creating a higher potential reward for hostile entities capable of disrupting their operations.[101] In some cases, compromising a satellite can be an expeditious way of attacking adversaries in an international conflict, and—as discussed in Part IV—a cyberattack of a satellite could be the most ius in bello-compliant way to perform an attack on a satellite.
Considering all the above, both government and commercially operated satellites must implement robust cybersecurity measures to ensure their protection. These measures include encryption of data, secure communication protocols, intrusion detection systems, and continuous monitoring to detect and respond to cyberthreats promptly.

E. SATELLITE CYBERATTACKS AS INTERNATIONALLY WRONGFUL ACTS
1. General Discussion Regarding Cyberattacks as Internationally Wrongful Acts
Even if uncertainties exist, numerous states, including the U.S., hold the view that the current international legal framework adequately governs the conduct of states in cyberspace. According to international law, a cyberattack could fall along the spectrum of international responsibility, use of force, and possibly armed attack. The boundaries between these scenarios are not always clearly defined.
International responsibility comes into play when there is a violation of an obligation attributable to a state. An international wrongful act—which is a foundational principle in customary international law—causes a novel legal relationship to arise between states when there is a breach of an international obligation by one of them. In fact, the breach triggers a shift from a primary rule—which is a rule dictating state conduct—to a secondary set of rules of responsibility. Article 2 of the Articles on State Responsibility for Internationally Wrongful Acts (“ARSIWA”) defines an international wrongful act as a conduct—either action or omission—that is contrary to what a State is required to do by international law, including violations of treaties and customary international law, that is attributable to the State. When the breach is attributable to a state, it initiates a new relationship called a “secondary rule,” which evokes legal consequences for the breaching state. Articles 28–36 of ARSIWA outline the legal ramifications of an internationally wrongful act. The legal framework aims to resolve disputes peaceably without escalating to war. It encompasses the obligation of the breaching state to cease the wrongful conduct, prevent its recurrence, rectify the situation, pay damages, or give satisfaction.
Rule 14 of the Tallinn Manual (“Internationally wrongful cyber acts”) provides that a state bears international responsibility for a cyber-related act that is attributable to a state and that constitutes a breach of an international legal obligation. The focus is on acts that are less severe than the use of force, but still carry international repercussions, such as the obligation to provide reparation.

## IV. IUS AD BELLUM AND IUS IN BELLO AND THEIR APPLICATION TO SATELLITE CYBERATTACKS
According to the proverbial expression "all is fair in love and war," in matters of love and times of war, almost any action is considered acceptable. This paper does not intend to delve into the accuracy of the statement concerning matters of love, but certainly the expression is quite wrong for wars, which are far from being unregulated in international law. In fact, armed conflicts are governed by two distinct bodies of law. The first governs the initiation of an armed conflict (ius ad bellum).^[189]^ The second governs the conduct of hostilities (ius in bello). This second body of law is also known as laws of armed conflict ("LOAC") or as international humanitarian law ("IHL").

Article 2.4 of the UN Charter provides that “[a]ll Members must abstain from the threat or use of force in their international relations against a state’s territorial integrity or political independence of any State, or in any manner inconsistent with the Purposes of the United Nations.” This provision establishes the principle of non-aggression, rendering the use of force, threats of force, including acts of aggression and military interventions, illegal against a state’s territorial integrity or political independence. Notably, it also prohibits any use or threat of force that contradicts the United Nations’ purposes. Three instances exist where the prohibition of use of force within or against another state is lawful: (1) that state’s consent; (2) authorization from the UN Security Council; and (3) individual or collective self-defense.
This paper does not discuss the topic of states’ consent or the UN Security Council’s authorization; and it focuses on the right of self-defense, as specifically relevant to a reaction to a cyberattack on a satellite. Self-defense is a principle of customary international law, which is also recognized by Article 51 of the UN Charter, which qualifies it as “the inherent right of individual or collective self-defense.” This right exists whether exercised individually or collectively by states (as under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization treaty). Under the principle of self-defense, a state is allowed to employ force when confronted with an “armed attack.” Nevertheless, the pivotal issue lies in the definition of an “armed attack,” which ultimately determines the applicability of the right to self-defense.
The UN Charter does not provide a specific definition for the term “armed attack,” and records from the UN Charter’s drafters provide no definitive explanation of the term. Scholars suggest that the inexplicit definition of “armed attack” may exist because the concept was thought to be self-evident. The drafters and negotiators consistently viewed aggression as the catalyst for justifiable self-defense. They

## B. APPLICATION OF THE NOTION OF “ARMED ATTACK” TO CYBERATTACKS
In modern conflicts, cyberattacks can disrupt critical information assets, communications, and weapons systems. Cyberattacks can also cause political disruption by targeting finance, energy, transportation, and government services, thus creating social unrest. In sum, a cyberattack can inflict damage well beyond that of a single bombardment. Can a cyberattack be classified as "an armed attack" under the UN Charter? Our discussion centers on cyberattacks existing independently of larger warfare contexts, such as the Ukrainian war. The focus is on singular or multiple cyberattacks that, devoid of any other military actions, could be perceived as acts of aggression against national security.

## 2. Ius in Bello and Its Application to Satellite Cyberattacks
The *ius in bello* governs the conduct of the hostilities, and has evolved over centuries. The *jus in bello* includes the laws of armed conflict (“LOAC”), alternatively known as international humanitarian law (“IHL”). This paper takes the position that IHL applies to conflicts in outer space, considering that the ICJ held that the IHL “applies to all forms of warfare and to all kinds of weapons, those of the past, those of the present, and those of the future.” Consistent is the Tallinn Manual, which unambiguously provides that “[c]yber operations executed in the context of an armed conflict are subject to the law of armed conflict.” However, contrary opinions exist. There is limited discourse on applying IHL to satellites in lunar or other celestial bodies’ orbits, which is not surprising considering the early stage of the lunar economy and the presence of only a few satellites around the Moon. However, once the principle of IHL applying in outer space is accepted, there is no reason to restrict IHL application to Earth’s orbits.
This paper only briefly outlines IHL principles and examines their application in space, specifically focusing on satellites. The following discussion will briefly cover: (1) military necessity; (2) distinction; (3) proportionality; (4) precautions; (5) the principle of constant care; and (6) the principle of avoiding widespread, long term, and severe damage to the natural environment. Military necessity mandates that any action in an international armed conflict must be justified as necessary to gain a clear military advantage. Distinction requires a clear differentiation between civilians and combatants, as well as civilian and military objectives with operations directed solely at military objects. Military objectives are those contributing to military action through their nature, location, purpose, or use, and when their (partial or total) destruction, capture, or neutralization provides a clear military advantage. First, the right of self-defense is a well-established norm of customary international law, solidified in Article 51 UN Charter. Its significance and authority are unlikely to be susceptible to influence by a provision framed in such broadly general terms as Article IV(2). Therefore, the right of self-defense must exist in outer space (contrary views exist). Second, in case of an armed conflict, ius ad bellum and ius in bello are lex specialix that prevail the OST. Article 103 of the UN Charter provides that in cases where members of the United Nations have conflicting obligations under the current Charter and other international agreements, the obligations under the UN Charter shall prevail. Third, the term “peaceful” under Article IV(2) should be interpreted as “non-aggressive” and not “as non-military.” The term “peaceful” also appears in the Preamble, Article IX, and Article XI. However, it is only in Article IV(2) that the term “peaceful” is paired with “exclusively,” creating a distinct regulatory emphasis on the Moon and other celestial bodies. Some scholars have pointed out that this is significant to give a special regime to the Moon and other celestial bodies, no matter how the term “peaceful” is interpreted within the OST, the crucial point lies in how Article IV(2) combines it with the term “exclusively.”

## B. THE OTHER SPACE TREATIES AND INTERNATIONAL SPACE ARRANGEMENTS
### 1. The Other Space Treaties
After the OST was enacted in 1967, several other significant treaties were signed between 1968 and 1976. These treaties, namely the Rescue Agreement, Liability Convention, and Registration Convention, also pertain to Moon activities and Moon satellites. None of these treaties are highly pertinent to the subject of this paper, except for the Liability Convention, which could be relevant if a cyber-attack results in measurable damage for which the victim-state seeks compensation.
In 1979—the Moon Agreement was signed—and it could have had the potential to significantly influence the subject of this paper. However, this treaty ultimately failed due to the limited number of ratifications. Therefore, while differing opinions exist, this paper contends that the dismissal of the Moon Agreement by the vast majority of states (including all major space-faring nations except India and Australia) renders it largely irrelevant for our analysis. However, as previously discussed, it can still serve a purpose when employed in a contrasting manner to enhance our understanding of the interpretation of OST. In other words, if the Moon Agreement found it necessary to address a particular issue, it implies that the OST does not cover that aspect.

## B. NATO’s POSITION
The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (“NATO”), established in 1949 through the North Atlantic Treaty, is a political and military alliance created as a collective defense organization among North American and European countries, totaling thirty-two members. Collective defense is NATO’s bedrock: NATO members pledge to consider an attack against any of its members as an attack against all, triggering a duty to respond collectively. Equally significant is the aspect of defense planning, meaning that the members collaborate on planning their defense and developing military capabilities against security challenges. Also crucial is the aspect of cooperative security, which means that NATO cooperates with non-member countries and international organizations to promote security and stability, such as conventional military threats, terrorism, and hybrid warfare, and cyberattacks.
To comprehend NATO’s stance on cyberattacks targeting satellites, it is essential to recognize that the matter resides at the intersection of NATO’s position on satellite defense and its response to cyberattacks. NATO has been increasingly focused on protecting and defending its members’ satellites, considering that satellites are crucial to communication, navigation, reconnaissance, and military operations. In 2019, NATO officially recognized space as an operational domain “alongside air, land, sea and cyberspace.”

While China may not explicitly articulate military intentions for space in their policies or directives, and consistently advocates for the use of outer space only for “peaceful purposes.”

2. Russia
Notwithstanding numerous declarations to the effect that space must be reserved for peaceful purposes, evidence exists that Russia continues in the militarization of space. Russian space law—largely governed by Federal Law No. 5663—stipulates that space activities must adhere to legal provisions for safeguarding state secrets, military and commercial secrets, intellectual property, and exclusive rights. This suggests that the federal law acknowledges Russia's intention to utilize space for military purposes. Despite some progress in national security space capabilities, the Russian space industry is currently grappling with an era of stagnation.
Lately, Russia has heightened its efforts in developing antisatellite systems, with some of these efforts being publicly disclosed. Additionally, Russia has been engaged in the creation of orbital maneuvering satellites, potentially for tasks related to inspection and interception. The advancement in these technologies not only hints at Russia's intention to target reconnaissance and communication satellites, but also signifies a growing unease within Russia regarding the perceived weaponization of space by others. Given Russia's long history of imperialism, reasonable doubts exist that its advocacy for peace in space might stem more from its current limited space capabilities, rather than from a genuine desire for space to remain a sanctuary. ## VII. CONCLUSION
This paper has delved into the issue of cyber-threats for satellites in non-Earth orbits, particularly in lunar orbits, amid escalating cyber-risks. The growing cislunar and lunar economy will heighten vulnerability, especially for commercial lunar satellites lacking robust protection. Just as Earth-orbiting satellites have faced increasing threats, lunar satellites will be confronted with similar risks in the expanding lunar economy. With a limited number of satellites orbiting the Moon, this paper has drawn insights from threats facing Earth's satellites to anticipate risks for lunar counterparts, focusing specifically on cyberthreats. Cyberthreats pose unique challenges due to attribution complexities and scope of the right of self-defense. This paper has examined cyberattacks as international wrongful acts and as armed attacks, assessing affected states' rights to self-defense. Considering provisions in the UN Charter and the OST, this paper has concluded that Article IV of the OST cannot be interpreted as impeding the right of self-defense of lunar satellites. Even if certain restrictions exist, this paper has argued that the right of self-defense would prevail when constrained by these limitations. Preserving security for both government and commercial satellites remains crucial for U.S. national interests, and it will become paramount on the Moon as well. The recognition that the right of self-defense is not diminished in space is an important component of satellite security.

A cyberattack—the focus of this paper—is a form of non-kinetic attack being carried out by digital means to compromise, disrupt, or damage data, infrastructure, or communication. The term “cyberattack” has several definitions, including the following: “deliberate actions to alter, disrupt, deceive, degrade, or destroy computer systems or networks or the information and/or programs resident or transiting these systems or networks.” Cyberattacks are performed through malware, hacking, denial-of-service, and other tactics aimed at compromising or disrupting computer systems, networks, and data. A cyberattack can aim at stealing sensitive information, or causing system malfunctions, or blocking the system (unblocking it only after the payment of a sum of money called ransomware). Cyberattacks are not the only possible form of non-kinetic attacks. Articles 6 and 7 clarify that organs provided by one state to another and actions by state entities, even when exceeding authority, are considered state acts. Articles 8 and 9 define state acts as actions under state control or exercised in the absence of official control, both qualifying as state acts. Articles 10 and 11 address actions of insurrectional movements as state acts, attributing related conduct to those states. NATO’s POSITION The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (“NATO”), established in 1949 through the North Atlantic Treaty,³⁶⁵ is a political and military alliance created as a collective defense organization among North American and European countries, totaling thirty-two members.³⁶⁶ Collective defense is NATO’s bedrock: NATO members pledge to consider an attack against any of its members as an attack against all, triggering a duty to respond collectively.³⁶⁷ Equally significant is the aspect of defense planning, meaning that the members collaborate on planning their defense and developing military capabilities against security challenges. Also crucial is the aspect of cooperative security, which means that NATO cooperates with non-member countries and international organizations to promote security and stability, such as conventional military threats, terrorism, and hybrid warfare, and cyberattacks. To comprehend NATO’s stance on cyberattacks targeting satellites, it is essential to recognize that the matter resides at the intersection of NATO’s position on satellite defense and its response to cyberattacks. NATO has been increasingly focused on protecting and defending its members’ satellites, considering that satellites are crucial to communication, navigation, reconnaissance, and military operations. CONCLUSION This paper has delved into the issue of cyber-threats for satellites in non-Earth orbits, particularly in lunar orbits, amid escalating cyber-risks. The growing cislunar and lunar economy will heighten vulnerability, especially for commercial lunar satellites lacking robust protection. Just as Earth-orbiting satellites have faced increasing threats, lunar satellites will be confronted with similar risks in the expanding lunar economy. With a limited number of satellites orbiting the Moon, this paper has drawn insights from threats facing Earth's satellites to anticipate risks for lunar counterparts, focusing specifically on cyberthreats. Cyberthreats pose unique challenges due to attribution complexities and scope of the right of self-defense. This paper has examined cyberattacks as international wrongful acts and as armed attacks, assessing affected states' rights to self-defense. Considering provisions in the UN Charter and the OST, this paper has concluded that Article IV of the OST cannot be interpreted as impeding the right of self-defense of lunar satellites. Even if certain restrictions exist, this paper has argued that the right of self-defense would prevail when constrained by these limitations. Preserving security for both government and commercial satellites remains crucial for U.S. national interests, and it will become paramount on the Moon as well. This paper delves into the legal complexities surrounding the protection of non-Earth satellites, specifically lunar satellites within the expanding cislunar space, and focuses on the emerging cyberthreats confronting these satellites within the burgeoning lunar economy, drawing parallels with Earth's satellite security to anticipate future challenges. Highlighting the intricate nature of cyber threats and their impact on both governmental and commercial satellites, this paper examines cyberattacks as potential international wrongful acts and armed attacks. This paper evaluates the right of affected states to self-defense and scrutinizes Article IV of the Outer Space Treaty ("OST"), alongside other pertinent treaties' provisions. This paper concludes that Article IV of the OST should not be interpreted as to impede the right of self-defense for lunar satellites, and claims that the inherent right of self-defense overrides the OST's restrictions, allowing for protection for lunar satellite assets.

This paper discusses the legal issues of protecting satellites in lunar (and other non-earth) orbits from cyberattacks. Lunar satellites are included in the "cislunar" space but present special characteristics that differentiate them from the satellites around Earth. This paper focuses on lunar satellites due to the expanding cislunar and lunar economy. This expansion is expected to result in an escalation of cyberrisks for lunar satellites—particularly for commercial ones, which have less robust protection compared to their military counterparts. Similar to Earth-orbiting satellites—upon which our economy has come to rely—which are facing growing threats from competitors and adversaries openly expressing their intention to disrupt these satellites in times of conflict, lunar satellites are likely to face the same threats, with the expansion of the lunar economy.
Due to the limited number of satellites currently orbiting the Moon, this paper analyses the threats faced by Earth's satellites and derives insights applicable to lunar satellites. ## B. WHY SATELLITES ARE PARTICULARLY EASY TARGETS FOR CYBERATTACKS
A satellite could be attacked kinetically or non-kinetically. “Kinetic” means actions involving physical force or direct contact, such as bombings and other types of attacks that cause physical damage, while “non-kinetic” attacks are those that do not involve a direct physical force. A cyberattack—the focus of this paper—is a form of non-kinetic attack being carried out by digital means to compromise, disrupt, or damage data, infrastructure, or communication. The term “cyberattack” has several definitions, including the following: “deliberate actions to alter, disrupt, deceive, degrade, or destroy computer systems or networks or the information and/or programs resident or transiting these systems or networks.” Cyberattacks are performed through malware, hacking, denial-of-service, and other tactics aimed at compromising or disrupting computer systems, networks, and data. A cyberattack can aim at stealing sensitive information, or causing system malfunctions, or blocking the system (unblocking it only after the payment of a sum of money called ransomware).

## C. THE IMPORTANCE OF SATELLITE CYBERSECURITY
Satellites play a critical role in many sectors, including national security, banking, weather monitoring, communication, and navigation.[100] Therefore, satellites are prized targets for cyberattacks. As countries increase their investment in satellites, they also grow more reliant on them, thereby creating a higher potential reward for hostile entities capable of disrupting their operations.[101] In some cases, compromising a satellite can be an expeditious way of attacking adversaries in an international conflict, and—as discussed in Part IV—a cyberattack of a satellite could be the most ius in bello-compliant way to perform an attack on a satellite.
Considering all the above, both government and commercially operated satellites must implement robust cybersecurity measures to ensure their protection. These measures include encryption of data, secure communication protocols, intrusion detection systems, and continuous monitoring to detect and respond to cyberthreats promptly.
